explain: Proftpd allows administrators to control which users or hosts can access the server using Allow, Deny, and Order directives. This enables fine-grained access control based on IP addresses, hostnames, or user accounts.
Proftpd can restrict users to their home directories or specified directories using the DefaultRoot directive, preventing them from accessing files outside their designated area (chroot jail).
Proftpd supports encrypted connections using TLS/SSL via the mod_tls module, protecting data in transit, including credentials and file contents.
With the mod_sftp module, Proftpd can provide secure file transfers over SSH, offering an alternative to traditional FTP with strong encryption and authentication.
Proftpd supports various authentication backends, including system accounts, LDAP, SQL databases, and PAM, allowing for secure and flexible user authentication.
Proftpd can restrict or control the execution of system commands by users, and with modules like mod_exec and mod_wrap2, administrators can define which commands are allowed or denied.

Proftpd has a modular architecture, allowing the use of security-focused modules such as mod_ban (for banning abusive users), mod_wrap2 (TCP wrappers), and mod_ifsession (conditional configuration based on session properties).
Proftpd validates user input and FTP commands to prevent injection attacks and malformed requests. It can also filter or restrict certain FTP commands for additional security.
Proftpd provides extensive logging capabilities, including transfer logs, authentication logs, and detailed session logs, which are essential for auditing and detecting suspicious activity.
Modules like mod_facl and mod_ban can be used to limit the rate of connections or actions from users or IPs, helping to mitigate brute-force attacks and abuse.
Proftpd enforces Unix file and directory permissions, ensuring users can only access files they are authorized to.
When using SQL-based authentication or storage, Proftpd's mod_sql module supports secure connections to databases and can be configured to use least-privilege database accounts.
Proftpd allows fine-grained control over anonymous FTP access, including upload/download permissions, directory visibility, and bandwidth limits.
Administrators can configure session limits, idle timeouts, and maximum connections per user or IP, reducing the risk of resource exhaustion and denial-of-service attacks.
The mod_hidefiles module allows administrators to hide files or directories from users based on patterns or permissions, reducing information disclosure.
Proftpd can integrate with TCP Wrappers to provide host-based access control, allowing or denying connections based on IP address or hostname.
Proftpd supports virtual users, allowing administrators to create isolated user accounts that do not correspond to system users, reducing the risk of privilege escalation.
The mod_rlimit module allows administrators to set resource limits (such as CPU and memory usage) for Proftpd processes, helping to prevent abuse and denial-of-service.
The mod_ban module enables blacklisting or whitelisting of users or IP addresses based on configurable rules, helping to block malicious actors.
Proftpd can automatically ban users or IPs that exhibit abusive behavior, such as repeated failed login attempts, using the mod_ban module.
